item.title: a (subjective?) handbook on majoring in cs @ mit
item.description: Having spent the last five years at MIT pursuing undergrad & masters degrees in cs, I want to write a handbook that I wish I had as a freshman. Disclaimer: This is mostly about pure cs at MIT (course 6-3); MIT has a eecs major (course 6-2), but since that wasn’t my major, only parts that overlap with 6-3 are addressed. While I try to be objective, these are, at its core, opinions.

item.title: about
item.description: hello, thanks for dropping by! my name is andy / andrew / yunta, and i am a 23yo software dev that does cs & (some) math. previously an mit grad student, currently a five rings capital dev in nyc. in the past, i have interned at segment, ebay, ibm, boomerang, and ucsf. you can find me on github, linkedin, quora, and keybase. my professional interests are ml / ai / statistical inference distributed systems performance engineering internet policy i love working on problems in fin / ed / healthtech, internet policy, startups, & esports.
